fields.value: Replication data for: Change Comes with Time

dsDescriptionValue.value: Although methodologists have provided us ample notice of both the problem of nonproportional hazards (NPHs) and the means of correcting for them, less attention has been paid to the postestimation interpretation. The suggested inclusion of time interactions in our models is more than a statistical fix: These corrections alter the substantive meaning and interpretation of results. Framing the issue as a specific case of multiplicative-interaction modeling, I provide detailed discussion of the problem of NPHs and present several appropriate means of interpreting both the substantive impact and the significance of variables whose effects may change over time.

publicationCitation.value: Amanda A. Licht. 2011. "Change Comes with Time: Substantive Interpretation of Non-NonPproportional Hazards in Event History Analysis." Political Analysis, In Press. article available here

files.description: This file will replicate all models and graphs discussed in the paper.  On a fast computer (quad-core running Stata 11-MC) it takes about ten minutes.  On a slower/older computer, it could take much longer than that (hours rather than minutes).  To run the file you will need to download all of the replication datasets available here.  Be sure to save them in the same directory, and then to change the <cd> line at the top of the do-file.  If you miss this step, Stata will look in the wrong place for the data files and will immediately stumble.  Running the do-file will result in a series of data files (containing the substantive interpretation variables and simulation output), as well as 9 graphs to be saved to your computer.  In all, these files will take up about 460MB of space.   Please note:  do not be fooled by the typo in Equation 8 of the paper,  the first differences should be calculated by subtracting the low value xj from the high value xi.   If you wish to utilize any of the data in the replication files for your own research, please contact the authors directly for permission and for detailed information on the variables involved.
files.label: Licht2011_CCwT_replication.do

dataFile.description: This file will replicate all models and graphs discussed in the paper.  On a fast computer (quad-core running Stata 11-MC) it takes about ten minutes. files.description: This .pdf provides discussion of the brief Monte Carlo experiment I performed to check the appropriateness of exponentiating the confidence bounds around the combined coefficient to acquire the confidence bounds of the relative hazard.  It also provides some generic code which may be more easily adaptable to other scholars' purposes than that in the replication do-file.
files.label: Supplement to Licht Chage Comes with Time.pdf

dataFile.filename: Supplement to Licht Chage Comes with Time.pdf
